ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to evaluate and critique major political and social aspects of recent American history and its effects on current times.
I learned a TON about American history since World War II. I learned how to form an argument from primary sources. A lot of fun.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are that the coursework allowed students to engage well with the class. The weakness is that the teacher was unclear in what she wanted students to express in their essays. The teacher did not teach students to engage with students about historical writing, but most of the class grades was on essays.

There was too much reading. I get that college courses have a lot of reading, and the number of pages assigned for this course may actually be less than pages assigned for more advanced courses. Coming out of high school, however, the level of reading can feel daunting, and I know many students who struggled to find time to read everything. In the beginning, I very much struggled to keep up. In the end, I was completing the reading with ease. This was progress, and I'm happy about that. Nevertheless, I know it was difficult for many of my classmates and, at times, for me, to keep up.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, the syllabus did not show the 15-page final exam paper that students only had reading week do complete. This oversight is indicative of the unstructured nature of the class. The work load was also greater than stated in the syllabus.
Yes, I would. You learn a lot and gain a very valuable experience working in the archives.
